newsitem.title: USA: American gets life for killing Swede in U.S..
newsitem.headline: American gets life for killing Swede in U.S..

text.p: A former police officer was sentenced to life in prison on Friday for the murder of a Swede who authorities once suspected in the 1986 assassination of Swedish Prime Minister Olaf Palme, a court official said.

Lamont Claxton Underwood was sentenced to life in prison for first-degree murder plus 40 years for kidnapping. A Watauga County jury on Monday convicted him in the death of Viktor Gunnarsson, deputy court clerk Richard Graham said.
Gunnarsson, 40, was among the first suspects questioned in the unsolved slaying of Palme, but eventually was released and later moved to North Carolina, although he never became a U.S. citizen.
Gunnarsson's nude body was found covered with snow in a remote mountainous area of western North Carolina on Jan. 7, 1994. Underwood was arrested on Oct. 12, 1995.

An autopsy determined that Gunnarsson's body had been in the woods for several weeks and the cause of death was two .22-calibre gunshots, to the head and neck at close range. Lengths of tape also were found near Gunnarsson's body, indicating that his hands had been tied, police said.
Prosecutors said Underwood was jealous over Gunnarsson's relationship with a woman both men had dated, and he kidnapped the Swede from his apartment in December 1993.
Underwood was a policeman in Salisbury, North Carolina, at the time of the killing.
At the trial, the prosecution presented 17 hairs found in the trunk of Underwood's car that were identified as Gunnarsson's through DNA analysis.
